>>52792446
Sacred Sword and Psycho Cut are non-negotiable choices, along with Agility ofc.
Gallade's last slot depends on your needs:
> Leaf Blade is your strongest coverage move and hits slowbro/king hard
> Knock Off is still goated and does good damage + utility
Tera wise, you have Fighting and Grass offensively (the latter with leaf blade) or Steel defensively to avoid priority and fairy moves.
EV-wise, 252 atk / 252 spe jolly allows you to wallbreak better without always needing an agility up; Life Orb gives you the biggest bang for your buck

posts.com:
>>52792446
To add to >>52793318 , investing in bulk is not worth it because you either become dependant on agility to do anything, or on Tera to do reasonable damage, and Gallade has the luxury of being powerful enough without boosts other than Life Orb / Muscle Band.
The third coverage move can be sword dance instead to wallbreak when the opposing team archetype demands it, but that leaves you walled by psychic types whic are still abundant.
Jolly is also the optimal nature because 80 is a crowded speed tier, but Adamant gives you a reasonable boost in power in exchange to losing to 110 speed scarfers like gengar (I would not advise to run adamant since jolly gives you the jump on positive 70/75 as well as a tonne of scarfers after an agility).
As previously mentioned Gallade is not dependant on tera which means you can tera some other mon on your team to cover dangerous threats and leave Gallade as late game option to sweep a slightly weakened team.
If using Gallade in draft leagues then the third coverage move can be literally anything since he's a green and white swiss army knife for whatever weird threat they have (on top of the fact that most of his coverage options are either sharpness boosted or above 100 bp).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The worst Gym Leader in the entire series, objectively. This isn't even up for debate.
>Final leader, supposed to be the strongest of the strongest
>Rhyhorn with pure Normal coverage, no STAB
>Nidoqueen with Scratch, Tail Whip and fucking Poison Sting as its best STAB
>Nidoking with Tackle, Horn Attack and Poison Sting
>No STAB on Rhydon, two OHKO moves
It's worth remembering that OHKO moves can't hit faster opponents in Gen I so both Rhyhorn and Rhydon are essentially unable to use those moves unless you're using like an underleveled Snorlax, Parasect or Slowbro. Those are pretty much the only Pokemon that can even theoretically get hit by Giovanni's OHKO moves.

BUT WAIT! THERE'S MORE!
>Giovanni has a Guard Spec. for each of his Pokémon, using it randomly 25% of the time.
Yeah. Not only is he using some of the worst moves in the entire game like Tackle and Poison Sting, but he also has a 25% chance with each one of his Mons to essentially waste a turn, doing nothing (Guard Spec. prevents the Mon's stats from being lowered, as if you'd ever be doing that instead of one-shotting his Pokemon with Surf).

Again, final Gym Leader of his region.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>52797930

The divisiveness mainly stems from Gen 1 being an absolute phenomenon with massive saturation via the games, anime, the TCG, the movie, all of the tie-ins (remember those Burger King toys that killed a kid?), which not only leads to a massive shitpile of nostalgia but also a huge preference in pop culture's memory - by the time the third gen was released the craze was long over, most of the fanbase had moved on to other trends and the people left invested were the diehards and the next wave of kids who got a Gameboy Advance for Christmas.

So you have three major groups: People who started with Gen 1 and stuck with the franchise, people who were there for Gen I for the year or so Pokemon ruled the world (possibly dipping into Gen 2) and then left the franchise behind, and people who never played Gen 1. Those groups all have completely different perspectives, and because anyone who was ever into Pokemon (especially in the late 90s) was fucking SUPER into it, there's a lot of passion.

Hence, we have the GENWUNNERS who think Charizard is the GOAT, because they remember his card was super valuable and they haven't cared to keep up at all with how the franchise has grown. And on the flipside you have Zoomers who have no idea what the big deal is about a boring dragon that isn't even a dragon. And these people especially get pissed because GF/Nintendo will always pander to the first group, because they are by far the biggest audience Pokemon ever had and nostalgia is a very marketable asset. And a lot of the frustration with that comes from other eras being disregarded/ignored completely.

>>52771160
Stop trying to deflect your inanity towards me, young man. The fact that you people can't understand the basic blocks of fictions should give pause to your statement. I don't find pleasure over this. in fact I've grown to find it even more icky than before. Realizing that Pokémon share the space of innocent natural creatures, to learn that their construction and attitudes mirror that of dogs and cats by choice and reading all these perverted posts is enough to give any decent person pause.

The issues isn't consent or that they're sexually active, the issue is that Pokémon don't occupy the space for it to be right. Pokémon are creatures that are treated like cats and dogs, that have the attitude of cats and dogs and are also creatures that occupy that space in-universe. They don't occupy the space of being people. These are creatures that eat dry food out of a dog bowl, that exhibit zoomies when excited and they also chew on shoes, these are creatures that simply want to be friends with you like a dog wants to be friends with a person. They're deliberately constructed to mirror creatures that are naturally affectionate towards humans in the real world and I bet many people can see that. It's a big part as to why Pokémon resonate strongly with people in the real world, despite being fantasy critters we can see how they reflect creatures from the real world. This becomes very apparent from reading the product guide from 2010 because TPC set guidelines up to safeguard this construction from 3rd parties.

In short Pokémon are not people, they're not human so we shouldn't impose anything on them. People here need to be honest with themselves and just admit they want to have these icky fantasies with critters that follow orders and are socially subordinate to their trainers who also have the mannerisms and thought process of dogs. No ones owes you to play into these delusions and mirages, let's be honest with ourselves without sugarcoating.

No. Digimon does that and Digimon has it's roots with v-pets. Some games even include a poop mechanic and Digimon "trainers" are called Tamers. But being otherworldy and being living computer data/yakai give them some leeway.

By comparison Pokémon doesn't construct Pokémon for fear of slavery comparisons. It does it because Pokémon at it's core is an idealized version of Satoshi Tajiri's childhood. Reading his biography it becomes crystal clear that the whole premise evolved from his own childhood, verily indeed his biography starts out with him dreaming of being a child again and instead of bugs he finds Pokémon. Pokémon are the little critters Satoshi Tajiri caught as a child, the little critters that he took care of and studied and captured so that's why Pokémon are the way they are, they're idealized fantastical critters based off the ones Satoshi caught as a child.

Verily so it has nothing to do with your nonsense. Pokémon act the way they do because they represent the critters that Tajiri interacted with as a child and also because he himself sees Pokémon as creatures that are like cats and dogs. That's why Pokémon particularly take after dogs in treatment and bsvahior.

>>52789624
which pokemon types would be considered the hardest/ most dangerous to train? Which would be the easiest?

Which husbando has the most scars?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52789791
(1/2)
>Normal
Rarely double typing with anything dangerous, probably good for domestic environments
>Fire
Hard to train because many have open flames or very hot bodies. Unless intelligent enough to regulate their fire not good for beginners
>Water
Seem to have a mild temperament and be easy enough to handle, especially if not evolved
>Grass
Probably still easier than fire types but Pokemon with poison attacks or thorns can be tricky
>Flying
Mostly safe like normal. Evolved forms are mostly no good for inside housing
>Fighting
Many strong willed Pokemon in this category, hard to train because they genuinely need to respect their trainer before listening to commands. High energy so need a lot of attention
>Poison
Hard to train, dangerous to humans even if they don't do it on purpose. Temperament depends highly on the exact species
>Electric
Small ones like the pika clones are very safe. Generally easy to befriend
>Ground
Like Rock they need a special environment for training. Not suitable for urban areas, otherwise mid diff to train
>Rock
Like ground the biggest challenge isn't to properly train them but more so where you find a good place to be able to do so without destroying a city
>Psychic
Second hardest to train after Dragon. Extremely intelligent so establishing yourself as the pack leader isn't enough. Also exceptionally strong. Not advised unless you have experience already
>Ice
Pretty hard. Be prepared for a lot of frost bite. Don't train in lone wilderness unless you know exactly what you are doing and that you can trust your Poke entirely

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52789951
(2/2)
>Bug
Same as Grass, but has more naturally aggressive species
>Ghost
Third most dangerous. Not beginner friendly, known to actively attack humans.
>Steel
Tie with Dark types in complexity. Steel types are mostly not flexible in the role they can take in a battle so you need to be a good strategist. Also day to day it might be an issue due to size and weight to have them around
>Dragon
Hardest to train. Big, territorial and aggressive. Intelligence varies.
>Dark
Tied with Steel. Not as inherently dangerous as the top three but can fuck you up.
>Fairy
Have very strong personalities. If it's a friendship evo you're set. If not you are screwed in most cases and will have to invest a ton of time. It's not really hard to train them but tedious and time consuming

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
A rival is someone who is meant to be a parallel and equal to you, a mirror image, an antithesis, a reflection of progress that you must overcome. Goku and Vegeta, Naruto and Sasuke, Dante and Vergil, Yugi and Kaiba, Red and Blue, light and dark. A satisfying rival will seemingly be on a wayward path, but your frequent encounters and clashes keep them grounded and trying to match you. You serve to elevate each other, though the rival will obsess over beating the protagonist while the protagonist is more reactionary and sees the greater picture.

Many later Pokémon rivals are pushovers as characters. They don't mind losing, they praise you, they choose the starter weak to yours. Rivals seem to have a common story arc of acknowledging themselves as weak, but where later Pokémon rivals falter is that they never really acknowledge themselves as strong or have much of an ego. They just start out with no preconceptions, lose a lot, and accept that maybe they're not that good. There is no lesson on humility because the rivals are already humble. They come off as punching bags. But maybe Game Freak decided that these kinds of characters are what modern players found to mirror them.

If you think I'm about to let a basement-dwelling 4chan prisoner try to school me on what I study for a living, then you have another thing coming. Look, the target demo has very little to do with who's ACTUALLY buying these games in this instance. Barbie games are targeted towards little girls who do play with dolls anymore, and yet dozens of 30-something-year-old male YouTubers purchase them for their "let's plays."

Now, a company may adjust their strategies to the actual buyers, but that is NOT the case here with Pokemon because you autists buy the games regardless. The franchise was designed for children to outgrow it and make way for the next set of toddlers, not granddads who jerk off to Umbreon plushies on the sewer of the clearnet.

TPCi and GF's entire marketing strategy is extremely kiddy and autist coded. All their Directs are bright, colorful, and light and accompanied by a gentle tutorial voice carefully describing and guiding the child through what's happening on-screen. The games feature easily digestible plots, lengthy tutorials, one-dimensional characters, toyetic designs, etc. "Kanto pandering" is a retarded meme, and it's relatively minimal in their ad campaigns, unless you count Pikachu and Eevee which are mascots. Its inclusion has little to do with attracting grandpas.

Pokemon is and always will be a child's franchise. It doesn't matter what your fanfic meta says or whatever bullshit you come up with to try to make it otherwise. It's not the end of the world if you enjoy it. YoU lOsE, lardass. L.

basically, the idea is to dig, then copycat your dig with prankster.
prankster means copycat has priority, moving first and dodging the other guy's attack with dig invulnerability, then dig moves last on the second turn because of lagging tail (or just min speed), dodging the second hit. (it also hits dark types on this turn because it's no longer prankster boosted)
then you just copycat again and repeat the cycle.
as the guy above you mentioned there are a myriad of ways to stop it, but it's fun to style on retards with.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
When I was a kid, I didn't have internet.
I guess internet became cheaper at some point, because one day we would get internet despite my family never making more money then we always did.
But I digress, I had cable, and I had video games.
One day Pokemon was on and James was being followed by a Cacnea, something clicked, I feel in love with it.
I would draw it constantly during school and at home, and as someone in a poor area with no access to public internet, I didn't know what it or if it could evolve into, so I got to work.
I looked all over Ruby for it, and eventually I finally found one.
I would finally be able to see what it becomes.
I just needed to keep leveling it up, to what level I didn't know, but I kept at it all week.
Now I should mention that I was only allowed to play my Gameboy for 1 hour a day, so keep that in mind as I spend the most of my time playing just grinding against the Pokemon in route 111.
Maybe it's a form of Stockholm syndrome, but the daily grind endeared me to Cacnea, and eventually the fruit of my labor, Cacturne.

posts.com: I keep coming back to Emboar even though he’s not that popular and is even a bit ugly (though I think that’s fine since he’s a boar after all). I love the art style of Wind Waker and Emboar always struck me as fitting in to that. He’s also got a great shiny. His description says he cares deeply for his friends so I’ve thought of him as someone who appears at first glance to be a dumb brute but has more intelligence and emotional depth than he seems. I don’t really think he translated well to 3D though- they seemed to give him even less of a neck and made his eyes smaller. I wasn’t really into Pokémon when B/W came out so I didn’t experience the initial disappointment of a third Fire/Fighting starter in a row that soured so many people to him. I hope that he appears in a future game and maybe has his model updated.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Didn't care for these little guys back in gen 2. Then gen 4 came around and I heard about the flinchlock shenanigans from a friend who used Smogon, so I tried breeding in the egg moves. After days of trying to get a decent nature (while secretly hatching eggs at work), I finally got one I was happy with and tried him out. He swept entire teams. He took out a Dialga AND a Mewtwo in the same battle. He beat a hacked, perfect IV version of himself. I asked /v/ for a name and the first thing they randomly gave me just happened to be the street I grew up on. I briefly kept him in Pokemon Ranch, where all the other mons would follow him around like a marching band. After unlocking Ranch's Mew, I brought him through every subsequent game.

He single-handedly made Dunsparce my favorite Pokemon. And, given the weirdness of 4th Gen IDs, there's apparently a 1/4 chance of him evolving into a 3-segment Dudunsparce when Home gets SV functionality. I might just keep him the same and carry Eviolite, though.

All hail Willis the Dunsparce.

>>52802354
it is old (finished around 2012 i believe), made before the decomp came out, only has 386 pokemon from gens I-V and the story is pretty stupid
however, it is one of my favourite hacks ever
it has aged nowhere nearly as poorly as light platinum
you can catch all the gen I-IV legendaries and 8 from gen V, and they each have minigames
it has 2 main regions (Tunod, which is OC, and Johto) and one semi-region (Rankor, 4 gyms + world championship) which brings the total to 20 gyms + world championship + legendary events + battle tower
the updated version some redditor made updates movesets and abilities and fixes
it is easily a top 5 hack of all time, and the fact that it was made so long ago is unbelievably impressive
also, don't use the website, download pre-patched here:
https://www.pokeharbor.com/2022/01/pokemon-glazed/

Step 0, upgrade your units, if you’re trying to 10k CSMM your DPS and tank should be at least Lv130 (preferably higher). Always EX your commonly used supports first for that double sync buff. Level your strong DPS pairs to 150 so they can get the job done faster.

Step 1, teambuilding, ideally your DPS should be getting to +6Atk/SpAtk +3 crit ASAP. Your third slot can either go to a debuffer/status/terrain setter if applicable, another support to heal/top up buffs, or a secondary DPS to deal with the sides faster.

Step 2, come up with a plan and know the turn order. 9 moves to the first sync = 3 moves per Pokémon, plan out these first 9 moves. Reset if necessary if you need MP regen on a trainer move to max your buffs.

Step 3, learn to quad queue, this will let you get in two syncs before the opponent’s first sync. The gist of it is, after you’ve queued nine moves, instead of immediately queuing the next two moves as they become available, you’ll want to wait for the sync countdown to reach 0, queue sync move first, then queue up moves on your other two Pokémon, then immediately queue another move after the sync finishes.

That’s basically all it takes to be “good” at this game.

posts.com: Australia easily has the most potential for the best designs. Unlike Spain or France or New York, the “idea” of Australian environment and wildlife is deeply ingrained in the public consciousness. This is what made Alola so great from a design perspective, everyone knows the stereotypes associated with a tropical island so it can easily carve out a distinct identity. Australia-based region would also be prime opportunity to make use of convergent evolutions, because literally the entire gimmick of IRL Australia is that it has marsupial versions of common mammals.

I like how nobody played SMD so nobody knows who this is, but it's the correct answer. It's a living accumulation of all evil and hatred in the world, able to (and did) kill Arceus, whose main objective is to kill everyone by launching the planet into the sun. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Giovanni: Bad person, unapologetic, but has his principles and a deep respect for power
Maxie/Archie: Idiots who believe they are doing the morally right thing by changing the environment
Cyrus: Isolated man who believes that all conflict in the world is tied to the incomplete spirit and seeks to create a perfect logical world like the machines he grew up around
Ghetsis: Real bastard with no principles, morals, or scruples, just wants power for himself, cares about nobody but himself, believes he's better than everyone, lies constantly, throws mentally deranged tantrums when he doesn't get his way
Lysandre: Wants to rid the world of the filth that he believes makes it ugly, seems to value virtuous traits
Volo: Lashing out at the world for its injustices, searching for a reason why they happen

Everyone else is mostly redeemed by the end or wasn't terribly bad to begin with. Underlings are just followers with the exception of Charon who has his own machinations but he's just a minor greedy guy. Faba is punished humorously, you're not supposed to treat him like a big deal. Team Star and Team Yell are just punks, delinquents, and hooligans rather than actually bad people.

Ghetsis is the worst person.

>>52800089
Cyrus isn't wrong. The cause of all conflict is the incomplete human spirit. He thinks the world is beyond saving and broken on a fundamental level which is why it needs to be remade from the very beginning. He disregards all good in the world because of his sterile and lonely upbringing. He doesn't have the bonds or experiences everyone else has. He has the resolve and magnitude to command followers and Pokémon but does not connect with them. He's treated more as a tragic character and later media has tried emphasizing the idea that he can be saved. Masters in particular resolves his character in a really good way. He comes to realize just how much his underlings genuinely care about him, how important he is to them and the virtues and strength that arise from this spirit that they display. He considers that rather than abolishing the existing world for being incomplete, it might be better to find a way to complete the human spirit instead.

posts.sub: Pokemon Scarlet and Violet Remove Long-Standing Female Empowerment Feature for No Reason
posts.com:
Pokemon Scarlet and Violet's character customization becomes more inclusive and filled with options, but a 9-year-old feature is cut for no reason.

For the most part, Pokemon Scarlet and Violet introduce great new features or further improve on the foundations laid by others in the past, which makes Gen 9 one of the best mainline games released so far even considering performance issues. There is arguably a much higher level of attention to detail in Gen 9 than other game in the franchise, to the point that Game Freak added specific animations for how some Pokemon disappear from the overworld, for example. Character customization in Pokemon Scarlet and Violet has made significant leaps forward compared to Gen 8 alone, but it's not always a bed of roses.

A great example is that Pokemon Scarlet and Violet players can never take their school uniform off, nor change the way it looks outside of four predetermined outfits - one for every season. As such, players' freedom is quite limited because school uniforms are such an overbearing part of the whole outfit that it's hard to make anything else pop, especially considering that their colors cannot be changed. However, this is far from the worst issue that character customization entails in Gen 9, as Pokemon Scarlet and Violet completely remove the ability to wear skirts in Paldea.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Often considered a symbol of female empowerment, skirts and dresses have been part of Pokemon games for almost a decade now, as they were introduced with Pokemon X and Y. As such, Pokemon Scarlet and Violet removing both skirts and dresses entirely not only makes no sense, but it breaks a major tradition that had only helped the franchise grow thanks to trainers across the world being able to choose what their in-game avatars looked like. School uniforms always come with shorts and pants regardless of the character gender that players pick at the beginning of the game, which doesn't make much sense.

Pokemon Scarlet and Violet's gendered language is already a big issue within the game when Gen 9 seemingly promotes a more open approach to LGBTQIA+ representation both via its NPCs and the character customization menu, and the lack of clothing options doesn't help. Allowing players to wear skirts and dresses would have continued a 10-year trend that had no reason to be stopped in its tracks, to begin with. This makes even less sense when one considers how Pokemon Brilliant Diamond and Shining Pearl ended up including more clothing customization than Gen 9 does, accessories aside.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Still, LGBTQIA+ representation in Pokemon Scarlet and Violet is better than it's ever been. For instance, Rika from Pokemon Scarlet and Violet's Elite Four seems to be introduced as a non-binary character, and allowing all characters to wear skirts would have taken this further. While Gen 9 also features some prominent characters wearing a dress, with them being the sisters Ryme and Tyme, as well as Poppy from the Elite Four, and Tulip from the Alfornada Gym, skirts seem to be completely absent from Paldea. Thus, even good representation and character customization features don't shine as much as they would, leaving players wondering why skirts couldn't be included, to begin with.

Furthermore, if four characters in the entire game can wear a dress, making it impossible to do so for players stings even more because it's probably not a matter of character models, then. The reason why dresses were cut could be rooted in the design for school uniforms, but even then, skirts could have been made available to players anyway, which makes this point moot. As such, there is seemingly no answer to why Game Freak decided to remove a longstanding female-empowering feature that's been present since Gen 6, and it's unlikely that Pokemon Scarlet and Violet's DLC will fix this.

Japanese pronouns don't mean much in terms of gender either. You don't have "male" or "female" pronouns; rather you have pronouns "mostly used by males" or "mostly used by females" but whose exceptions reflect particular personalities, rather than gender identities.

See Bokukko and Ore Onna for example. "Boku" is a pronoun mostly used by boys, but a girl using boku isn't trans or non-binary, just a tomboyish girl and/or grew unaware of social conventions.

Similarly Ore is a "macho man" pronoun, and an "Ore Onna" is an aggressive or loudly bossy tomboy. One Piece's Big Mom is an example of Ore Onna

I think everyone here would agree when I say that quality > quantity, nobody cares about your "delivery-volume" when it's just requests put through an AI. >Large, muscular male
>Smug, calculating nerd
>Femme-fatale beauty

Ein and Arlo also both share similarities in that they're both credited with the creation of the shadow pokemon. Ein, Dakim and Venus also use the Johto trio as their signature pokemon/legendaries, which would have served as a direct parallel to Spark/Candela/Blanche using the Kanto trio.
Niantic clearly knows enough about Pokemon Colosseum since they ported the concept of Shadow Pokemon exactly as it was from those games, sp I think it's plausible that they originally wanted to bring back the three Cipher Admins, and then either found out they didn't have the IP rights for the characters, or decided to just rebrand the entire concept with a Team Rocket skin for nostalgia marketability.

>>52790545
Yes and no. The sets are relevant to what's in the tier. There could be a vital move for in game battle facilities that just doesn't see play in Smogon because none of the Pokemon it's good against are relevant in OU.

For example, Volcarona in Gen 8 OU is recommended to run Psychic instead of Giga Drain because of the relative lack of Water types in the tier that are weak to it. Psychic lets it hit Toxapex, which is neutral to Giga Drain, and Bug Buzz lets it hit Slowbro. Barraskewda dies in one hit to anything at +1, so it doesn't matter what you use. It's also stronger than Giga Drain on Urshifu-R. However, Giga Drain should absolutely be run on Volcarona in battle facilities because you're very unlikely to run into a Toxapex or Tentacruel or Pelipper, but there are plenty of Ground, Water, and Rock types that eat shit from Giga Drain in the Battle Tower.

tl;dr: The Smogon sets are a good baseline on how to use a Pokemon, but don't take them as gospel because they're relevant to the meta at the time they're written.

The problem is, how do you rule that without it becoming a nightmare? Do you ban the move on Pokemon with specific berries? For Gens 1/2, you're generally getting mixed attackers in the form of Normals with coverage for Grounds/Steels, Nidoking, Special attackers with Boom, or GSC physical sweepers with Skarm coverage (Machamp with Fire Blast/Wak with Fire move/T-tar with fire move etc). In ADV you tend to see more dedicated mixed attackers like Swampert, Mence, etc, but it's not a role you actively seek out. It's less "What mixed attacker works here" and more "Do I need this specific mon on my team"

I also see Garga sticking around, because being able to pivot into Ghosts/random status for free and get consistent progress with Salt Cure is going to be really, REALLY good. Frankly I see it singlehandidly shoving Pex out of the tier entirely because it just shits on it so hard

Treads, as I mentioned, will probably also see good use because it checks Koko and Lele, has Rocks, has Volt, and has a ton of really nice moves that make it good offensive support. If anything, I could easily see it taking the place of Corv on teams that don't need the Ground immunity

In general, even if Tera goes, I don't see the meta slowing down in any capacity. If anything, I see it taking that further shift away from walls and towards a more offensive/bulky offensive metagame, especially once all the aforementioned DLC shit drops. Also if Gliscor drops that shit is going on EVERY fucking team

One last note, I actually think Tusk will get a lot worse as time goes on and all the DLC mons come back. Losing to all the Tapus sucks so fucking hard, and if Glisc comes back it runs into extreme 4MSS

Krookodile is the definition of a "Perma UU" mon because it has a bunch of really good traits (Intimidate, Rocks, Taunt, decent speed, typing, and bulk), but also a bunch of traits that really stop it from cutting it in the big leagues (Speed that's decent but not decent enough, weak to common types, usually competes with the likes of Lando and other Ground rockers)

It's the case of "Good, but not good enough"

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52801259
It follows the same conventions as Magneton, Dugtrio, Metagross, Klingklang, Hydreigon, etc. It did just get bigger, but it also gained a new gimmick in the process. The whole point of dunsparce was that it was a stupid (dunce) pokemon that was rare to encounter (sparce) so in gaining an evolution it also gained value in the three segment form. With the way modern pokemon games are designed, theres literally no such thing as a rare pokemon. Things like Gen 1 Chancey and Gen 3 Bagon just cant exist. Modern games focus more on the AMOUNT of pokemon you catch, so the chance that 1/100 of them could be three segment, have an authentic pot, or experience child mortality is the best compromise. Dudunsparce is proof GameFreak still understands the appeal of their fictional monsters- something even the fans forgot.

Are you seriously telling me after having the most popular franchise of all time they seriously never considered at any point to design the games around reusing code to make less work for themselves in the future? People whine about graphics too much nowadays, that's true, but in a franchise like Pokemon there is NO EXCUSE for it to be as choppy as it is.

As for *longer* stories, I want to see the "Latias joins Ash's party for a whole region" idea played straight just one time. Just one time invent a set of circumstances where he goes back for her or she finds him and they decide to take on a region together and maybe kiss a bunch. I'm very partial to that and am working on a *very* long-form version of that story, unfortunately without the kissing and also a lot more stuff piled in that'll probably turn off anyone looking for Ash and Latias to kiss.

>>52784274
Yeah having an extended story with Ash and Latias basically asks for one of two things. Either Ash has to stay with Latias or Ash has to go back for Latias. He would never do the former because he has his journey and his dream to follow and he really wouldn't do the latter because Ash doesn't look backwards, he barrels onwards forever in search of his dream. Journeys was basically the only time you could write in a reason for Ash and Latias to meet again, since it involves him randomly stumbling upon locations he's visited before.
Speaking as a writefag myself, it took me forever to come up with a reason Ash would go back for her, and it legitimately relied on another character begging him to take some time for himself after a string of nasty losses AND him randomly deciding on Alto Mare because he found the picture Latias gave him earlier in the story. He's never taken a vacation before in his life and only comes to a decision on that because I had to air drop a big neon sign reminding him of it.

>>52793289
It's not about pets, it's about adventure. I was fortunate enough to grow up with the freedom to to wander a pretty large rural area with my dog anytime I wanted, and it genuinely shaped a lot of who I became as an adult. Then I could come home and Pokemon captured an even broader sense of adventure, travelling with cool, fantastical creatures and exploring what felt like an entire world.
Pokemon's core appeal is and has always been a sense of adventure and bonding with your favorite little creatures, which is a primary reason the more humanoid pokemon are widely panned.
Honestly you could make the argument that humanoid pokemon reflects a shifting childhood landscape (less freedom, less connection to nature... For various socioeconomic reasons) and so the designs are pivoting to capture a different generation's childhood reality.

Here's the thing. Looking past the nostalgia and bias, the entire core idea of going around, capturing creatures and making them beat the shit out of each other is somewhat unsettling. And I think GameFreak being vague about the exact mechanics of pokemon capture and why the wild monster who just tried to fry you is suddenly obeying you without question is a deliberate move to not draw too much attention to these issues. But then again the existence of humanoid, intelligent and blatantly sapient pokemon who can be captured just like your generic rats and pigeons does that anyway.
Then there's the fact that there ARE pokemon who exhibit personalities - Arceus, Calyrex, Mewtwo, etc. And then different continuities like anime and Mystery Dungeon straight-up make them actual characters with their own personalities, quirks and sapience, but still without adressing the elephant in the room that is trainer-pokemon dynamics.
Add all of that together and there's a big moral clusterfuck that GameFreak is too afraid to address, and the difference in pokemon portrayal even inside one game gives leeway to fans to interpret shit however the fuck they want, with opinions ranging from asinine "all of them, including the likes of Mewtwo, Calyrex and Arceus, belong on the leash, are too dumb to clean themselves and deserve to only eat from the floor" to an opposing extreme of "all of them, even your Magikarps and Ratata, have human level sapience and deserve to be treated as equals to humans". All interpretations have plenty of problems and GF isn't gonna fully commit to either one because they are too lazy and that's just gonna open a whole can of worms anyway. So all you can do is just consoom.

Oh I know. It's not even that hard to make pokemon work. I've seen anons suggest various ideas for how it works and these are my favourites. Basically, most pokemon naturally want to fight and become stronger, so when they are beaten or sufficiently impressed by trainer or his pokemon, they willingly accept capture in order to train under them and become better. Kinda like shonen antagonists who join protag's party after getting their asses beat by them. The whole system runs on pokemon recognizing and honouring trainer's strength, which is also why traded high level pokemon will not listen to you - you've yet to prove your worth to them, and only by beating 8 gym leaders and presenting their badges you can earn their respect. That interpretation dodges the whole "enslavement" thing and gives pokemon agency and intelligence, the only caveat being that majority of pokemon are naturally hardwired to fight and intent to grow stronger.

>>52793278
It's not that Tajiri didn't know what he was doing. Back in 1995, before the games released, Tajiri wrote a back on game design which he wrote about Pokémon and it's origins, in it he refers to Pokémon as Kaiju-like pets. Clearly he held that Pokémon should be like cats and dogs for a while, the panel from the comic is from when Pokémon was beginning to emerge from the capsule monsters concept. In reality Pokémon represent the animals Tajiri interacted with as a child, this much becomes apparent in his biography as the development of Pokémon progresses his childhood starts to become the main inspiration rather than Pokémon just being about trading and using the link cable. Indeed he rewrote the script of the games in six months because Ishihara thought the games had no coherent message.

So clearly it didn't spawn out of nowhere. The series has been consistent on that front and no amount of whining is ever going to change that. Pokémon as a series owes a great deal of success to the familiarity Pokémon posses. They're cute, they're fantastical, they have charm and in many ways they mirror creatures that people in the real world cherish. This is why The Pokémon Company has safeguards in the form of guidelines for 3rd parties and as to why they continue to construct Pokémon that way to this dat.day

Short version: giving pokemon personalities forces them into a box and therefore limits them to a narrower range of appeal.

Making them pet-like means they have broader appeal because how you feel about them is dictated by their design and your experiences with them in-game, and not by some game designer who view Lugia as a mother figure so badly they nearly drank themselves to death. posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
so I wonder why giant mons slow the game down in PLA. In theory, drawing something big would be about the same effort as drawing something close to you.
But you would also need to do things like possibly extra collision detections, as if its bigger its going to collide with more things.
I think one of the biggest problems though would be raytraced shadows. The resolution of a mon's shadow is more or less correlated to how big a mon is drawn. So the bigger the mon, the more detailed the shadow. But the bigger the shadow, the more rays you need to cast to calculate it, and ray tracing is slow. The resolution was hand-picked to be decently fast with normal-sized pokemon, but if you have a fuckhuge mon its gonna cast a shitload of rays and slow the game down.
One solution would be to make the shadow less detailed depending on the size, which probably would fix the problem outright.
You might also be able to get away with other methods of shadow rendering.

Regardless, its obvious that in PLA (maybe SV too) there's an algorithm being used that doesn't scale well.

Wasn't entirely sure on what rules to use for area encounters in Scarlet and Violet, but I saw that someone else used the Pokemon centers to split the Areas into smaller sections, so I went with that as well.
>Vs Katy
>Nymble
Nymble uses Struggle Bug, and Susanna strikes back with Aerial Ace. This repeats the next turn as well, with Nymble getting KO'd.
>Tarountula
Susanna hits Tarountula with Aerial Ace and gets hit with Bug Bite in return. Another Aerial Ace takes the spider out.
>Teddiursa-Tera
Susanna uses Silk Trap to slow Teddiursa down, blocking a Fury Cutter
Now faster than the bear, she hits it with Aerial Ace, and gets hit by Fury Cutter in return.
I don't want Fury Cutter to rise in power, so Silk Trap blocks the next strike.
Another Aerial Ace and Fury Cutter exchange leaves Susanna in the red, but with one final Aerial Ace, Teddiursa is defeated.

>>52717546
Starmie is really nasty, it has a +22.5% crit rate with Bubblebeam for an effective power of 65*1.5*1.8= 175bp off of 100 Special.

In RBY criticals don't do double damage, rather it's level dependent multiplier of (2*Lv+5)/(Lv+5). That means a Level 2 Rattata on Route 1 getting a critical only hits for 1.28 times damage.
I actually kind of like that, it makes the early game much less volatile, no one hit kills on an unlucky critical. And it's not like it affect competitive much since at 50 the multiplier is 1.9 and at 100 it's 1.95.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Hey friends, I've been wanting to relive the days when I actually enjoyed this fucking series, so I figured I'd do a Nuzlocke challenge like the good old days. Gonna play the era I enjoy, GBA/DS. Sort of a region-travel playthrough. FireRed, SoulSilver, Emerald, Platinum, and White.

Rules aside from the normal:
>Champion Clause: Any Pokemon, living or dead, that makes it to the HoF in one game has its line stricken from all subsequent ones. This includes split evos like Eevees or Hitmons.
>Set battle style
>Wild Pokemon and Starters randomized to within the same power level to make catches actually somewhat interesting in regions with poorly-distributed Regional Dexes

Starting off with a choice of Totodile, Pichu, or Ralts with Brock as my first gym leader makes things easy, though it does unfortunately give Boomer's rival, Zoomer, what he called "an easy dub no cap fr fr" with a two-shot Thundershock. Thankfully, I don't consider the Nuzlocke to start until after Rival 1, so here we go!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52791319
>Giacomo
>Pawniard
I send in Sceccu, not really expecting too much trouble.
Pawniard immediately humbles me a bit, doing pretty good damage with Metal Claw, but Stamina and Iron Defense makes sure the next one won't do too much, and a Double kick in return takes out Pawniard.
>Segin Starmobile
I think the Attack of my mon dropped here, but I don't recall what caused it.
The car Snarls at Sceccu(now down to 13 HP), and takes less than impressive damage from Double Kick.
I swap in Jock McGraw on Snarl.
The car lets out a Metal Sound, and Jock hits decently hard with Force Palm.
Swift sends Jock into the red, but another Force Palm does nice damage.
I send Blue Suede in on a Swift.
The Car snarls twice at the bird as it Aerial Aces. A third would kill Blue Suede, so I send in Douce Dame on on a Snarl.
A Metal Sound drops the special defense of Douce Dame far enough that I don't want to stay in after the Take Down.
I send Greensleeves in on Snarl.
Another Metal Sound is fairly meaningless, as Seed Bomb reduces the Starmobile to more or less a single point of health, which Quick Attack takes care of.
Pretty impressed with how much work the Starmobile actually had me put in.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52793062
Decided to activate the Kofu events and go to the Marinada auctions early, but I underestimated Kofu's underling Hugo, who took out Blue Suede with his Floatzel.
The fight against Iono was the last big one I did before Christmas, and boy, I completely screwed it up.
>Vs Iono
I had planned on beating her whole squad with Bulk Up Terastal Black Belt Hariyama... but somehow I forgot her first mon was
>Wattrel
Despite my mistake, I decide to double down and muscle through the bird. Jock Terastalizes as he Fakes the bird Out.
However, Air Slash does some decent damage next turn and Knock Off doesn't finish the bird off, meaning another turn of the same two moves follow, but Wattrel finally falls.
>Bellibolt
I no longer have the health or time to setup Bulk Ups, so I go directly for Force Palm. Bellibolt takes less than half, Charges up, and hits decently hard with Spark. If I don't swap Jock out, I'm losing here.
I send in Sceccu for free on Spark. Two Bulldozes deal with the frog, but not without a Water Gun crit doing nasty damage inbetween.
>Luxio
It intimidates Sceccu. A Bite does fairly insignificant damage, and two Bulldozes in a row takes out the cat.
>Lil' Lightbulb Mismagius
Sceccu almost gets reduced to red health by Hex, but gets a Strength in.
I swap in the mon I hope will be able to patch my mistakes: Ezy Rider. Hex does nothing.
Ezy Rider hits the Lightbulb with Breaking Swipe, doing really good damage. Sadly, Ezy gets hit by a Confuse Ray as well.
He hits himself, and Mismagius uses Charge Beam(SpA up!).
Another Breaking Swipe lands, putting Iono's ace into the red, but Charge Beam powers Mismagius up further.
I don't really have a safe switchin bar Sceccu(but I'm a bit frazzled at this point and his low health keeps me from picking him), so I stick with Ezy.
Sadly, he hit himself again, and the Charge Beam does just enough to down the lizard.
Douce Dame comes in to avenge him, and finishes the fight with Ice Shard.

>>52761880
That's awesome it got you into online competitive battles!
Here's my wholehearted suggestion as someone who finally got a damn grasp of what everything means back in Gen 6, play to have fun.
Focus on using favorites and build around them, try a number of team building styles to see which works best for you. Me personally I'm a fan of balanced and hyper offensive teams. I'd avoid worrying about numbers and entirely avoid meta picking. It's fine if a mon you like ends up being a meta mon, but there's truly nothing more soulless than an entire team of copy/paste meta sets.

Me personally I have used a number of my favorites, built teams around them, tried new pokemon I've never touched before, made new favorites, and have accomplished breaking numerous top 500 tiers to varying degrees in both single and doubles across 3 generations.

Pokemon is about having fun catching and using those pokemon for battle. The mechanics aren't that difficult to teach, and I'd honestly extend the offer to teach you myself if you want a personal better understanding.

Despite the valid dissenters and those that have never played pokemon competitively about showdown, it's an excellent resource in trying new things on a dime without much commitment, so you find out what DOES work to then commit to it in game, which by the way has been made a billion times easier this generation compared to ones prior, an absolute massive win in my opinion!

If you'd like to know an omega powerful set with Polteageist, have a mon that is capable of setting up psychic terrain, have it faint or switch in on a prediction that involves you not getting hit (it's risky), make sure your polteageist has weak armor, a focus sash, and shell smash with stored power, shadow ball and a fairy coverage move for dark types, and you will have a borderline unkillable sweeper, the likes only other sashed mon can deal with or a scarfed ditto.
The psychic terrain helps out massively because it blocks ALL priority moves so you won't get gibbed by a revenge killer.

Pokéclicker is an open-source game built around the story and content of the Pokémon games. This is an idle & clicker type game that is currently in beta release phase. New content and patches are released frequently.

>Crobat?
https://crobat4.github.io/pokeclicker/
A modified version of Pokeclicker that features QoL changes from the original, including a Dock shortcut, type-based pokeball selection, Gen 3+ berries being available in dungeons, un-nerfed experience gains, and some egg-exclusive pokemon being available through other means.

>Wiki
https://pokeclicker.miraheze.org/wiki/Home_Page

>CODES
Start Menu > Save > Enter Code
>OOOSHINY
Free shiny
>FARMINGBOOST
10,000 Farm Points and 100 Cheri Berries
>CROBATISBASED (Crobat fork only)
Awards a Rotom (Crobat)

>Encounter tables, best places to gem/EV farm
https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1IxPh59_lNxZUa3Qo3r5ZbawGHL_nfqqd
>Various forecasts
https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1HFK5gS4XDmqXvZPP8stBYGC9ZF77i-Wug2J_gcmJ5rw
>Check your save for missing pokemon
https://cypherx.github.io/pokeclicker-missing-util/

Baffling to me an open source browser game in 2022 won't even allow discussion of modding while real games include mod suppport, encourage modding, or even integrate mods into their games as features. Beyond being silly, they're killing off the scriptDev-to-gameDev pipeline. You've got a niche group of people who know how to code, have spent time getting familiar with the game's code, and are invested enough in the game to write for it. They're low hanging fruit for recruitment, but if they drop into the Discord they'll find that even discussing scripts is enough to get you branded by a condescending mod. It's not just a few people either: the main script github repository has 238 forks and 144 stars compared to 247 forks and 391 stars on the games actual repo. That's a lot of developer investment to spit in the face of.

.According to Zuo Zhuan (左傳), before primordial China was united by the Yellow Emperor (黃帝), tribal rebellions ran rampant. During the fabled Emperor Yao’s (堯帝) reign, there arose four clan leaders who were particularly disobedient, namely Gonggong (共工), Huandou (驩兜), Gun (鯀), and Sanmiao (三苗). In order to punish their defiance, Yao banished all four barbaric communities. When the rebel leaders died, they continued to haunt the region as the “Four Perils.” Gonggong resurrected into the qiongqi; Huandou became the hundun; Gun reincarnated into the taowu; and Sanmiao took the form of the taotie. As for why they ravage the lands as who they are, it is speculated that the tribes used to carve these chimerical creatures on their totems to display reverence.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>52774636
>What went wrong?
Gen 1 and 2 Pokemon were designed so that they could be rendered in a 56x56 sprite on a tiny black and white screen and still be recognizable. That's why they're mostly simple shapes, that's why they're mostly based on animals and objects, that's why they have limited textures, colors and surface details.

As the technology advanced the designs became more complex and colorful. There are Pokemon now that would be impossible to accurately render under the restrictions of OG Gameboy hardware.

Think of it like this anon. Restaurants will have a food inspector come to visit and inspect to see if everything is above board. So the pokemon league sends out an inspector from time to time to see if everything is fine. When they are not around, a gym leader might basically do what is known in pvp stuff as "win trading", the challenger takes a "loss" but gets a badge and the gym leader gets to keep their job. The Cerulean Gym used to have a fairly noteworthy reputation as being the easiest of the gyms. Also welcome to the shudo-verse, as to elaborate
>Win trading was a thing he envisioned.
>In addition, if a gym leader lost 3 or 4 times in a row, they lost their position.
>The job market in pokemon was considered scarce of positions, and while being a gym leader had a fairly crappy wage, it was better than being homeless.
Brock became a stronger trainer, but he mostly washed his hands of being a gym trainer outside of moments like putting on a demonstration for the alolan students. Misty meanwhile has gained a reputation as one of the hardest gyms to challenge.

posts.com:
Notable ones include:
>Ninjask
Having Speed Boost and Swords Dance + Baton pass is an extremely good thing, and shows that sometimes abilities and movepools mean more than mere typing
>Butterfree
In the early days of Sword and Shield, G-Max Butterfree saw considerable play as being the only Rage Powder user in the format, along with being able to dish out extremely accurate Sleep Powders. It also had Tailwind and could GMax into something that could spread many statuses. It was not to be taken entirely lightly early on.
>Vivillion
Any Bug with Quiver Dance is usable at worst.
>Masquerain
Oddly enough, Masquerain is becoming the premier Sticky Web setter in the current meta because it gets Intimidate as well.

>>52801392
Wide Guard is good to protect against multi-target moves, if your pokemon is an Iron Valiant it will be weak against Posion, Psychic, Fairy and Steel. There are two big multi-target moves going on about now, Make it Rain (Steel) and Expanding Force (Psychic) and the usual suspects (Eq, Muddy Water, Heat Wave, Icy Wind, etc). Corvi resists some of them, but in the end you'll have to do the calcs on the moves and consider that the enemy might expect Wide Guard and go for double single target moves, in which case your Corvi will do 0 to help it.
Other than maybe bounce an Intimidate if you rock Mirror Armor, which might be good enough by itself to prevent your Valliant to go -1. Really you have to check your whole team and what people are picking.
Reminder that Iron Valliant is not legal in VGC rules (ranked) yet.

>>52775814
To those asking about Special Delivery Bidoof. It's significantly more rare than the other two cards. That adds to its price. You had to opt in to special promotional emails and the text was buried within. Then you had to enter a lottery (which not everyone got selected -- like the charizard -- but even more exclusive), then you had to be picked. It was to commemorate the opening of the Canadian Pokemon center site.

On top of that, I heard rumors that TPCi actually RAN OUT of the bidoof cards. So if you placed an order near the end of the eligibility dates with your code, there was a chance that they actually ran out of cards. It's the rarest of the three and will likely be the most expensive.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52787250
Prefixes such as "Dark" werent used until Rocket Set.
Prefixes such as "Cool", "Flying", "Surfing", "_______'s" and potentially "Team Rocket's" could fall under the Rocket Set.
Team Rocket's Meowth doesnt use the same card configuration as the Gym series. Which Sabrina's Abra does within the Blackstar Promos.
The point i'm trying to make is Gym Sets, and Rocket Set are interwinded into baseset through the Blackstar promo cards. Keep in mind, no Johto mons show up until neo.
So Base, Jungle, Fossil, Rocket, Gyms, and 1-28 of blackstar are all generation one. But you could consider rocket & gyms an expansion.
